We still have a few spots left in our free, hands-on bicycle maintenance workshop Tuesday, August 27, 6:30-8:30! Email or dm us to register!

A regularly cleaned and maintained bike lasts longer between repairs, rolls smoother and more efficiently, and is more enjoyable and safe to ride. The good news is that you can do this at home, without the need of any special tools.

Our facilitators will share easy-to-follow techniques and tips. Please note: this is a hands-on workshop -- we will practice the general steps of cleaning and maintaining on your bike as a group. If you have any questions, please reach out to us!

The “Learn-tBike Workshop” aims to provide a free opportunity for people of all ages, backgrounds, and abilities to learn how to ride a bike. This workshop has a limit of eight participants, with a possible addition of two The “Learn-to-Bike Workshop” aims to provide a free opportunity for people of all ages, backgrounds, and abilities to learn how to ride a bike. This workshop has a limit of eight participants, with a possible addition of two more if they are able to provide their own bicycle.

🚲Thursdays (starting August 8), 5:30-6:30 PM on the UofT St George campus
🚲Participation is free of charge
🚲No prior experience required
🚲Bikes and helmets will be provided if needed
 🚲Learn from certified cycling instructors and experienced cyclists
 🚲Get a free helmet for completing all four sessions
🚲Check out and pass on link in bio to sign up!

Our Film Night is happening tomorrow on the second floor of the GSU Pub from 6:30pm - 11pm.

Our Miniature Mondays happen every Monday at the Student Commons from 5pm - 9pm!

Play some miniature war games and try to beat your opponent. Feel free to set up a game in advance so you and your opponent are prepared. Or you can just show up with your miniatures and see if you can do a pick up game.

You can also paint miniatures at this event, so come out and socialize with others while you assemble and paint your miniatures. Never assembled or painted miniatures before? First time attendees are able to build and paint a miniature free of charge (we'll assist you along the way)!

Members get free access to our entire range of paints and hobby supplies (non-members can access them for $5), which is great if you need that one colour and don't want to buy a whole pot.

Our General Game Night happens every Friday at the Student Commons from 6:30pm - 11pm!

The University of Toronto Tabletop Gaming Club is open to everyone, even those not affiliated with the University of Toronto.

We'll have games from our board game library, people will be running RPGs, there'll be card games, we'll have miniature war games present, and we'll be playing video games. Attendees are always welcome to bring games from their own collection or bring their own consoles.

RPGs being run at this event will be posted to the one-shots channel of our Discord. If you would like to run an RPG or have any questions, feel free to send us a message or email uofttgc@gmail.com.

We're hosting a GM101 this Friday!

If you're interested in learning how to run an RPG then this is the event for you. The GM101 is system neutral as the principles can be applied to any system, and it's designed for those with limited experience with RPGs.

Event runs 7:30pm - 9:30pm at our General Game Night; if you miss this event don't worry, this will be a regular monthly feature starting in September.

Our Gaslight Gatekeep Girlboss Gaming event is happening next Saturday August 31st from 3pm - 7pm at OISE in room 5290 (252 Bloor Street West)!

This is an event specifically for women, trans, and nonbinary players. This is not an event for cismen.

We're going to have some board games from our collection, we'll have Jackbox Games available, and we're set to have a Call of Cthulhu game run. People may also watch a movie during the event. We will provide some snacks.

The UTSU Food Bank aims to address food insecurity on campus by operating a free, year-round service open to UofT students in need of food. This service provides support to individual students and students with families. Support your fellow students by helping them access healthy, nutritious food!

To apply, send your resume and cover letter (in PDF format) expressing your interest and your availability to services@utsu.ca.

You can find more information at utsu.ca/work-volunteer (link in our bio). If you have additional questions you can reach out to services@utsu.ca.

Applications will be received until Friday August 23, 2024 or until all positions are filled.

Today we met with the University of Toronto Graduate Students’ Union (UTGSU), University of Toronto Mississauga Students’ Union (UTMSU), Scarborough Campus Students’ Union (SCSU) and University of Toronto Students’ Union (UTSU) in our first Students Union Coalition Meeting!☺️

We are excited to work together this upcoming year to continue to build on the successes of the student movement - organize events, provide cost-saving services, and mobilize our base to continue our fight for free and accessible education and a just future. 

#StudentsUnitedWillNeverBeDefeated #ThisisYourStudentMovement

Join us at the September AstroTour on Thursday, September 5! The event is FREE and open to all. NO PRIOR REGISTRATION REQUIRED!! Our September AstroTour features PhD Candidate Dang Pham's talk on comets at 8:00PM, followed by exciting astronomy demos and telescope tours at 9:00PM!

Talk abstract : Comets at night and the Sun during the day have always mesmerised humanity. Studying how comets move around the Sun is one of the oldest problems in theoretical astrophysics. In this AstroTours, we will explore what comets are made of, how they move, and how you can spot them! Then, we will explore what will happen to comets billions of years from now, when the Sun will have exhausted its nuclear fuel and become a white dwarf — a dead star. 

Image Credit: https://news.mit.edu/2017/scientists-detect-comets-outside-our-solar-system-1026

Don’t miss out on this vibrant start to the year, we’re so excited to see everyone there!

From all of us at the IRC: welcome home!

Howdy Innis residents! The IRC is once again hiring!

A position on the IRC is a great opportunity to get involved with the Innis community, develop as a student leader, and advocate for yourself and other residents. You’ll also be running or assisting with a variety of events targeted towards residents.

To apply or learn more about the positions, scan the QR codes above or visit our website (innisirc.com). If you have questions, feel free to reach out to Nicole Jacquette at vpinternal@innisirc.com or Wing Yip at vpcomm@innisirc.com (for questions specific to SMM).

The deadline to apply is September 10th 11:59 pm, but interviews are running on a rolling basis so apply ASAP if you're interested!

No problem heres the information about the yugioh world championships 2024

The Yu-Gi-Oh! World Championship 2024, also abbreviated as WCS 2024, is an upcoming Yu-Gi-Oh! Official (OCG) and Trading Card Game (TCG) tournament that is set to be held in Seattle from 7-8 September 2024, being the most prestigious and final event of the 2023-2024 season.
It will be held alongside the Yu-Gi-Oh! Duel Links World Championship 2024 as well as the Yu-Gi-Oh! Master Duel World Championship 2024[1]. For the first time ever, the Duel Links World Championship will be split into two separate categories, namely Speed Duel (the traditional format in Duel Links) and Rush Duel (which was added to the game in September 2023). However, the total amount of players for the Duel Links category will stay the same as the Speed Duel tournament has been reduced from 24 to 16 players, and the newly added Rush Duel Championship will only have 8 competitors.
Meanwhile, the Master Duel category has been increased from 8 to 12 teams, now also including players who qualified by making first place at a Duelist Cup or collecting Season Points.

This tournament will mark the first World Championship in North America since 2016. It's also going to be the latest World Championship ever, as the tournament had almost exclusively taken place in early to mid August before.

As of mid August 2024, all competitors across all categories are known.

No problem heres the info about the 2024 pokemon world championship

The Pokémon World Championships are the pinnacle of competitive Pokémon play. Typically occurring in August of each year, the Pokémon World Championships feature the best Pokémon players from around the globe. Players will compete in the three-day event for a prize pool of over 2 million dollars (the highest prize pool in the Championship Series circuit), the title of Pokémon World Champion, and return invitations for the following year’s Worlds.

The 2024 Pokémon World Championships will be held August 16–18 in Honolulu, Hawaiʻi.

Players qualify for Worlds by earning Championship Points at events throughout the Championship Series season. Pokémon TCG, VGC, and Pokémon GO players must hit a threshold of Championship Points to earn their Worlds invitation, whereas Pokémon UNITE teams must finish near the top of the Championship Point rankings in their rating zone. The number of Championship Points required to receive an invitation is based on both geographical rating zone and age division.

The very best players will receive an award for travel to attend the event.

Players in Japan, South Korea, and the Asia-Pacific region will be awarded World Championships invitations as per their regions’ organized play and esports programs. Players from these rating zones are not eligible to earn World Championships invitations through Championship Points or through automatic invites earned by winning Regional or International Championships.

The Madrid System, also known as the Madrid Protocol[1] or simply Madrid, is the primary international system for facilitating the registration of trademarks in multiple jurisdictions around the world. It was established pursuant to the multilateral treaties Madrid Agreement Concerning the International Registration of Marks of 1891 and the Protocol Relating to the Madrid Agreement (1989), which has been the sole governing treaty since 2016.[2]

The Madrid System provides a centrally administered system for obtaining multiple trademark registrations in separate jurisdictions; it does not create a single unified registration across different jurisdictions, as in the case of the European Union trademark system.[3] Rather, applicants file a single international trademark application and pay one set of fees to apply for protection in any or all countries that are members of the system; each country has discretion to grant the application. Once the trademark authority of a designated country grants protection, the mark is protected in that jurisdiction just as if that office had registered it.[1]

The Madrid System is administered by the International Bureau of the United Nations World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO) in Geneva, Switzerland. As of February 2023, the Madrid System consists of 114 members covering 130 countries;[4] known collectively as the Madrid Union, they represent more than 80% of world trade.[4]

Are you passionate about sustainable development, volunteering abroad and empowering communities to achieve a higher standard of well-being? Are you looking to build skills and gain experiences you can leverage in your future career? Then apply to be a U of T Global Brigades executive.

UTGB partners with local communities in Central America to implement holistic and sustainable development programs that aim to resolve health and economic disparities.

We are now accepting applications for multiple executive positions. As a member of the executive team, you will meet like-minded individuals who are passionate and work together to achieve the mission of Global Brigades. OLAS and CALMS will be hosting the Bridging Past, Present, and Future in Latin American Health: Student Symposium event this fall!

At this event, we will be providing a medium for students to network and communicate with Latin healthcare professionals, researchers, academics, and community health workers to discuss how we can better health outcomes for the Latin American community in Toronto.
We hope to provide mentorship and support to Latin students wanting to enter a healthcare field, however this event is open to student, person, or staff interested in the conversation at hand.

The event will take place September 17, 2024 from 5-8
